Subject: Unit testing Antlr
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.21.0103192027070.8964-100000@...>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
From: Joi Ellis <joi@...>


I've written a spike using Antlr to reverse-engineer a grammar. I need
to parse legacy product config files with Java.

I now need to decide how such a beast will be unit tested, and I'm wondering
if anyone else has designed unit tests for exercising Antlr-generated
parser classes.  I looked around the mail archives and the websites and
didn't find any mention of Antlr anywhere.

I want to create a collection of ascii texts and ensure the parser reads
all of them properly.  The result from my spike parser is an actual
object, not a string, so I guess I need some way of creating an
'expected result' object, the input text, and comparing the parser's
returned object.

Has anyone done this sort of parser testing before?  Do you have any
suggestions or pitfall warnings I should consider before I dig myself
in too deep?

I'm guessing a single unit test might look something like this:

  public void test1() {
    DebugConfig expected = new DebugConfig(1,2,3,4,5,6,7);
    String testInput = "debugLevel { config 1\n ...}";
    StringInputStream in = new StringInputStream( testInput );
    Parser foo = new com.aravox.parser.DebugConfigParser(in);
    assertEquals( expected.toString(), foo.toString());
  }

I don't know if I want to have a bunch of methods like this with 
strings hard coded, or if I want to somehow store the test input
and some serialized form of the expected object in a single file.

I'm also not sure if I should create a separate method for each
test string, or just make one big method out of it.  I'm thinking
the former, so that one failure doesn't kill all remaining tests.

I lean toward the above  'cause I already know how to do it, even 
if it does mean hardcoding the test inputs as strings in the test code.

Any thoughts?

-- 
Joi Ellis                    Software Engineer
Aravox Technologies          joi@..., gyles19@...

subject: Unit testing Antlr
